title: Which U.S. presidential candidate will have raised the most campaign money as of 30 September 2020?
preds: More records set after Tuesdays debate (RIP American politics) by the Biden campaign. Impossible to see how Trump could come out ahead here. 99 to 100.
Biden was ahead of Trump at the end of August. With the recent passing of RBG, the Democrats have gotten a huge surge to seal the deal.
As Trump goes deeper in his craziness, people that can’t imagine another four years feel obliged to fight, and to give money.
Republican funds are being focused on Senate Races. Biden will win the money contest.
Latest open secrets comparison is hard to argue against
Seems like a negligible chance at this point that Trump's September numbers make up the over $100 billion deficit currently shown up to around the end of August on OpenSecrets.

Biden was 30 million back according to open secrets including outside groups as of Sept 8 but not including August fundraising. Biden's August fundraising exceeded Trump's by 150 million. So unless the situation reverses in September it seems guaranteed that Biden will have the larger fundraising.
Using the crowd as my floor, but this is higher than I'd prefer. Not wrong necessarily, just a bit... heightened.

Many reports out now about Trump campaign woes and record setting Biden hauls. If they were at all close coming into August, they aren't close anymore and the gap is likely only to grow moving forward.

Trump has been leading Biden in fund raising until August.  At the end of June, they are about even (at about $400M).  At the end of July, Trump led Biden by about $40M [1].  But Trump's lead was reversed by the end of August, with contributions to Biden exceeding Trump's by $155M, resulting in Biden total contributions leading by $115M.  This reversal is likely due to the excitements generated by the two national conventions in August. I don't expect this trend to change in September for the following reasons.   (1)  There is nothing in the campaign calendar that could affect voters excitement - the first presidential debate is on September 29, too late to affect the contribution reporting for the end of September.   (2) The stock markets are at their highest levels. Moving even higher will not affect Trump contributors that much. (3) Black Lives Matter protests and related unrest have peaked, reducing these events as Trump's wedge issues for fund raising. (4)  I expect the contribution level to drop significantly to the pre-convention level (about $100M a month).  At this level of fund raising, it will be difficult for Trump to catch up by the end of September. Note that I am only talking about by the end of September.  Events beyond that could change the election and the contribution levels, such as the performances in the presidential debates and the potential availability of a Covid-19 vaccine in October.    [1]  https://www.opensecrets.org/2020-presidential-race
Revising up based on August fundraising numbers. Non-campaign fundraising is still a wildcard but seems more likely it's Biden.
Biden claims to have raised 364 mil in August. https://www.zerohedge.com/political/fishy-hell-graham-slams-actblue-over-anonymous-donations-after-group-drops-nearly-200

Campaign committee figures.
Biden end July = 321m + 364m according to press in Aug = 685m end Aug
Trump end July = 414m + 210m according to press in Aug = 624m end Aug
Need to add on outside groups for end Jul, for which Trump is slightly ahead.  So fundraising isn’t that far apart.
Over half of Trump funding comes from small donors, vice versa for Biden.  During Sept which is likely to rack up more value?  I guess large funding can bump the numbers up quicker, and it seems more large funders might be behind Biden.  But Trump has a large dedicated following willing to support who might keep pouring money in through small donations.  Feel like this is quite difficult to call.  Trump might drop a pile of personal money in (assuming he has it, not a given since his wealth comes from the hotel business and the murkiness of his finances) just so he looks good in the last few weeks of the campaign.
Edging Biden as trend in recent months has swung his way.

Numerous reports and leaks suggesting the Trump campaign is strapped for cash and has begun consolidating and cutting spending on TV advertisers while Biden has broken multiple fundraising records in recent weeks.

The Current Incumbent said the other day that he would donate great lashings of cash to his campaign if necessary.   Last time he said this, what happened instead was he loaned money to the campaign at a generous rate; if they paid it back it was gravy, and if they didn't it was a tax writeoff.   There is so far no evidence of this or any other action, though, so perhaps he was just bloviating.  Apparently that happens sometimes.  Anyway, after due consideration of whatever this means, I'm leaving my number where it was.   Might be wrong, but in times like these one yearns for stability, even if it's artificial or even imaginary.
So, if my math is correct, Biden is up about $114 million on DJT with a month left in this challenge. I can’t foresee any circumstances under which Team Trump can dig out of that hole.

H. Clinton in 2016 raised more than 2x the funds raised by D. Trump. This year, J. Biden is more popular and a far more consensual choice by the Democratic party, which gathers the support of more liberal republicans. Latest news points to the possibility that D. Trump will have to allocate his own funds in the race. Therefore, it is very likely that J. Biden will raise more campaign money.
Huge $ haul for Dems in August....Trump campaign signaling money issues.
Some of Trump’s big donors gave pulled back and the way his money was spent might turn off some donors.
DT is considering spending 100 million of his own money.This indicates that fund raising number might be lacking
Biden might actually raise more money after Trump found himself lacking in funds suddenly.

Trump is now considering spending $100 million of his own money on this campaign [1]. Brad Parscale overspent by a LOT, nearly $800 million, and right now the Trump campaign is having to dial back spending on basic things like advertising. This would not be the case if they had pulled in enough for August. [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-08/trump-weighs-putting-up-to-100-million-of-his-cash-into-race

If Trump raised more in August he would have announced it with trumpets on Aug 3. The fact that it's the 8th and we are still waiting to hear tells us he raised less. Still, Trump was coming into the month with a ~$30M lead. Leaving my forecast at 50/50.
+10% to Biden on reports of record breaking August. Can't find anything about Trump numbers yet.
Biden has already raised more than Trump.   He has the momentum.   Trump will continue to put his foot in his mouth, limiting his ability to catch up.

DJT’s campaign has yet to announce August numbers, five days into September. Despite their capability to spin bad news and, shall we say, take a few liberties with the facts, not coming out with an announcement yet signals a truly dismal take in comparison to the Biden campaign’s August haul.

Adjusting to the realisation that Trump would announce superior numbers if he had them. I don't think his words matter anymore, and we know he likes to win, I would not be surprised if he reports a massive August haul, for us to discover in 6 months its was illegally sourced and misrepresented.

Recent replay of alleged POTUS comments regarding US military men who have lost their lives in combkat in Middle East, AfPak, as well as John McCain and the reference to those who served in World War I are bound to have a ripple effect.  Many years ago I drove along the old Route Nationale 3 in eastern France and stopped at the a few of the American military cemeteries around Verdun.  The karma is bound to come around.,

late on the trigger here, but with a record setting month for Biden I can't possibly remain confident that Trump will out-raise him before 30 Sep. The Trump Campaign has yet to release their August numbers, which indicates that they don't come close to Biden's, and that they're still trying to figure out a way to spin the narrative in their favor. September will be an all-out fundraising month for Trump so that his campaign can regain the fundraising narrative going into October and the last 30 days before the election.

I presume that the Trump brand is reaching a level of toxicity that may discourage big name sponsorship despite the potential favorable palm greasing effect that donors would hope to enjoy. 
WWIII might be good for business, but arguably bad for existing. Wouldn't it be wild if after his term/reign, DT retired in Russia? You heard it here first.

Ok Trump ahead in July and record haul for Biden in August. Trump numbers for August not out yet. Some of his big donors are sitting out or slow in donating. 62 days left. Edge to Biden pending Trumps August numbers.

Reports are rolling in that Biden raised a record $300 million in August alone, blowing out the campaign numbers of both candidates combined in 2016 for the same month. It is also notable that by most accounts a lot of the increase was driven by grassroots efforts, an area in which Biden had struggled in previous months. https://www.cbsnews.com/news/joe-biden-campaign-300-million-fundraising-committees-august/
Biden significantly outraised Trump in August.  I generally think fundraising favors the incumbent, but if it looks like a Biden victory, big money will start buying access if they haven't already.

No forecast change. Looks like a record month for Biden in August. Of course, DJT could announce a similar haul, but I expect there to be a significant gap.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/01/us/politics/biden-trump-fundraising-election.html

Trumps ahead and the lead will grow in the wake of the shootings. No safety is offered by the DNC, they were supporting the riots and railing against law enforcement for too long and too late to change course. Democrats are bleeding their base and grass roots funding in the process. Biden isn't as charismatic as Clinton, the tide is turning and no-one bets on the losing horse. Radical change is required to alter their current trajectory.

Not sure on this one. Trump raised more in July. Some if his big donors are sitting out but his position on taxes low for the rich might result in donations. Just do not know. Check august when those numbers come in.

But you can keep them for the birds and bees
Now give me money
That's what I want
That's what I want, yeah
That's what I want"

Pretty short amount of time for Biden to make up quite a big difference, while Trump is still raising money himself, and it seems like the difference is not even going particularly in the right direction for Biden. Trump apparently raised more money during the RNC than Biden did during the DNC. https://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/514225-trump-campaign-rnc-raise-76-million-during-republican-national-convention https://www.newsweek.com/trump-campaign-raises-6-million-more-during-rnc-biden-did-during-dnc-1528502
If August shows Trump then I am reversing. https://www.npr.org/2020/05/20/858347477/money-tracker-how-much-trump-and-biden-have-raised-in-the-2020-election

Positive trend for the Democrats stopped. Just two months and a few days left, October was reported as a month with lower raising success in the 2016 election campaign. Funding also seems to be correlated with a candidate's personality and his supporters fear of or longing for change. Republican supporters' fear of change might prove to be stronger than Democrats' longing for a new governement.

Since my second prediction (first adjustment) 4 days ago, the following has happened: Biden has raised 7.000.000$ and Trump has raised 14.000.000$. The gap is now more than 40.000.000$ wide and the trend has apparently reversed. With Trump raising more than Biden both from AUG 10->AUG 22 and AUG 22->AUG 26. I am adjusting slightly again, holding out on changing anything dramatically prior to around 1 month since my original prediction. At that time, the inside view (current trend, current numbers) should also outweigh the base rate which overwhelmingly suggests Biden should win. What I haven't had time to look into, is the timing of various PACs and funds going in. A lot suggests that much of the money being risen will still happen over the next month, meaning that a lot can still change.

I’m flipping, because my previous belief that Biden would overtake Trump during the summer hasn’t materialized. I see Trump holding up. And November is just two months away now. Biden’s funding has to speed up to convince me to change back.
Trump's donor base is has more to lose and is desperate to win.

Politico reports that the top 4 fundraising days in Biden's campaign have come within a week of Harris' announcement as VP (https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/19/kamala-harris-democratic-donors-398656). $25.5 million in one day, $48 million in 2. With Biden down less than $40 billion overall at the beginning of the month, Harris' winnings appear to have single handedly made up the gap. With Biden already gaining on Trump and both political parties having their conventions this month one would assume they would have similar opportunities to raise additional capital. Many saw Biden's speech as a best-case-scenario for Democrats while Republicans have, at best, a controversial line-up for their convention and Donald Trump speaking every night. I think with the success of his VP pick spurring a comeback, Biden has a slight edge in the coming month.
Hedging ahead of the GOP convention, not based on anything other than the known unknowns

Numbers now at; Trump - $504B
Biden - $469B With last update on July 31st (somehow)

Reviewing the available info at the Center for Responsive Politics, Trump is still ahead by $50 million. I don't know how often they update their data, but I'll expect a fundraising bump for Biden coming out of the Democratic convention. Likewise, I believe we'll seen a subsequent fundraising bump for Trump after this week. I think its especially impactful that Trump will have an appearance each night - he is a showman, and knows what his voters and general viewers want: to see him say outrageous things so that they can either confirm their positive bias or reaffirm their negative bias. Regardless, this will translate into dollars for the campaign. For those also forecasting the outcome of the General Election (and there are several questions that are basically asking the same thing), look at the percentage of donations coming from small individual contributions.... Trump is meaningfully ahead in that category. Another site to track monthly totals: https://www.npr.org/2020/05/20/858347477/money-tracker-how-much-trump-and-biden-have-raised-in-the-2020-election

I read today one of Trump’s main funders in 2016 is sitting out. https://politicalwire.com/2020/07/24/trumps-most-important-2016-donor-sits-out-2020/
https://www.casino.org/news/las-vegas-tycoon-sheldon-adelson-fund-president-donald-trump-reelection/

Since my first prediction, Trump has actually widened the gap slightly. With Biden now @ $462,675,633 and Trump @ $490,355,288 according to OpenSecrets. The base rate and overall trend over the past 4 months both still heavily point towards Biden being the overall campaign funding winner in 38 days. I am adjusting my prediction slightly (1%) in Trump's favour, and will be watching this closely. Both candidates are likely more than 150.000.000$ away from their final campaign funding if the election does indeed end up being the most expensive yet, in which case the current. 28.000.000$ in difference between the two is a relatively marginal gap.
hedging back to 50/50  (from 75/25). Biden got a bounce from the convention. I'm less enthusiastic about his chances than the crowd here.
Biden leads now, and as Nov 3 approaches even fierce  right wing potential Trump contributors will think twice before putting their money.
ramping up the biden chance trump money just came earlier this year

Harris choice will help Biden fundraising 15 Minutes of Reading: done Forecast: Slight advantage Biden because Harris pick will help him and his campaign fundraising has been catching up to Trump's. However, Trump outraised Biden in July and is currently slightly ahead.

The OpenSecrets links show Biden PACs out-earning Trump PACs. I don't see any reason for confidence, so until I see more reporting I'll give Trump the slight edge. https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2020/08/06/election-2020-trump-tops-joe-biden-fundraising-25-m-july/3307215001/
I was thinking this for a while... also the Delaware angle is compelling: https://www.npr.org/2020/08/17/902626429/wall-streets-big-money-is-betting-on-biden-and-democrats-in-2020

Biden's announcement of Harris has driven a spike in donations. Many reports indicate the Wall Street and Silicon Valley support Harris as a VP, meaning that there is a much smaller chance they take sides and donate large amounts of cash this cycle. Trump also continues to flip-flop on messaging and has difficulty coming up with a comprehensive plan for either the virus or his second-term, which will make it difficult for him to bring on new supporters and donors in coming weeks and months.

Joe Biden's recent announcement of Kamala Harris will encourage more people to donate to his campaign. Joe Biden's current polling, which shows a sizable lead is also a big indicator. Joe also shows evidence of being able to pulling in larger amounts from PAC's.
Ok Shelden Adelson, the biggest donor to Republicans in 2018, has yet to contribute to a PAC that helps Trump. Changing a little.
Silicon Valley will bring out the big guns
Thwre are already clear indica ion that Biden fundraising is going to be well ahead than Trump's
Dems will out perform GOP by far

With Kamala Harris onboard, $26mln were raised on day 1. Impressive and seems to outpace Trump's fundraising. I expect that as time goes by, funds will flow to the likely winner, who I increasingly believe will be Biden (but that's a different forecast question!). So I am now joining the camp of Biden-will-outpace-Trump.

Momentum is on Biden's side. Trump filed for reelection on the day of his inauguration and has been aggressively fundraising ever since for reelection, so that Biden is essentially tied with Trump at this stage suggests he will outpace Trump in the final months of the election.

Trump began raising money for his election immediately after his 2016 election.  Biden has only been raising money for a little over a year.   So the momentum is on Biden's side.  His recent VP announcement should help him raise even more money.

trump on small contributions vs biden on large ones
buisines favours biden
much of trumps funding by retired people -> limited pool of donors
Gave Biden the edge... hoping the addition of Kamala Harris to Biden's ticket will bring in more money and supporters.
Biden has had surprisingly strong fundraising.  If he looks like a highly likely winner, the cash (buying access) will significantly increase.  Historically the advantage goes to the incumbent.

Current wave of grass roots and corporate funding appears to favor Biden even though Trump has a 3 year head start. Momentum will favor the challenger in this area. People always want to invest in the winner vs. the loser, and with current polls Trump is looking like a loser.
Trump is already sitting on a significant stockpile and will maintain a lead.

History says Democrats raise more:
- In 2016 Hillary Clinton raised significantly more than Trump:
https://www.bloomberg.com/politics/graphics/2016-presidential-campaign-fundraising/
- In 2012, Obama raised more than Mitt Romney:
https://www.nytimes.com/elections/2012/campaign-finance.html
- In 2008, Obama raised more than McCain:
https://www.politico.com/story/2008/11/2008-campaign-costliest-in-us-history-015283 But today's 2020 money race has left Biden behind:
https://www.npr.org/2020/05/20/858347477/money-tracker-how-much-trump-and-biden-have-raised-in-the-2020-election?t=1597143215122

Reasons
1. The Democrat super PACs are fund raising at a record pace. And have already outpaced the Republicans by a 4:1 margin. The Democrat donors are determined to get the WH while Republican donors are thinking twice. 
2. Trump has pissed off his biggest donor Sheldon Adelson 
3. Republicans are fund raising to hold the senate and not the WH
Flip-flopping. After reading Politico today, seems Team Trump fund raising efforts are paying off.

Trump beat out by Biden last month. I wouldn't be surprised to see major Republican donors stepping up, especially after the conventions and after Biden's VP pick. I am a Biden supporter, but Republicans are resilient in their spending.

BASE RATES:
Relevant options for base rates would be:
a) How much money is usually raised in US presidential campaigns?
b) How often do Democratic candidates, Republican candidates and tertiary candidates out-raise the others?
c) How often do a sitting president out-raise a challenger? Across the 2016, 2012, 2008 democratic candidates have out-raised republicans considerably. Including Trump vs. Hillary in 2016. George Bush out-raised Kerry marginally in 2004. Tertiary candidates are not worth considering whatsoever in how much they raise given the current trend.

Obama raised more money than his competitors John McCain and Mitt Romney. Hillary outspent Trump $142 mil to $92 mil. Look on Opensevrets.org at the heavy hitters doners and they tend to favor Democrats.
https://www.opensecrets.org/news/2008/05/data-update-heavy-hitters/

Joe Biden has caught up to Donald Trump in a very short amount of time. He currently has momentum and with a landmark VP candidate on the horizon, he is set to eclipse Trump in fundraising by small donors. There are already several normally huge GOP donors that are sitting out this election.

Trump is pro business, pro economy, pro American.  Biden is in his basement.  Trump is spending his campaign money, which naturally drives the demand for additional campaign money.  Biden is paying for his son's legal fees and tax fines.
Biden out raised Trump in June. Trump out raised Biden in July. The rich will probably give to Trump because he will oppose tax raises. There is the Bloomberg factor. Tough one.

Trump busy being Trump. Still anybody's day...
https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/08/trump-antagonizes-sheldon-adelson-phone-call-392688?cid=apn

Less than being strategic, this is a hard one to have strong feelings about. I don't feel there is a clear-cut "favorite" bucket to win this, and the rationales prior to mine bring up valid points... they are compelling, albeit contradictory.  https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/05/politics/biden-trump-fundraising-july/index.html

i dont understand the crowdforecast
trump is fundraising since he won in 2016
biden just started recently and has almost overtaken him already
most people now think biden will win (i dont, but it doesnt matter) so people will want to give him money to have influence on the next administration
Trump will raise the most money as billionaires will fund him, but Biden will do alright with lots of small donations along with some corporate sponsorship.

After more review, I’m going to change my original forecast and weight more heavily for Biden. Trump seems to be handling fundraising with the same level of competence with which he’s running the country. https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/08/trump-antagonizes-sheldon-adelson-phone-call-392688
Until today Trump Has lead in from racing and I don’t see that changing

Donald Trump is currently ahead by only $6 million. However, he has raised over $72 million more than Biden from small dollar donations, which are more likely to be recurring payments that last until the election in November. While Biden does have a $10 million advantage in larger contributions, that gap is just as likely to shrink as grow in the coming months are each campaign continues to wine and dine large donors. Moreover, Trump's voters are more than twice as likely to be enthusiastic about voting for him than Biden's voters (68% to 31%), and while excitement may not translate into votes, it definitely translates into donations. Also, it was announced this week that the NY AG is going after the NRA, which Trump is already using to stoke fears about second amendment rights among his base. Fear also translates into money, so this will also likely become a big talking point as the president continues his campaign. All of this, when combined with the traditional incumbency advantage, means Trump will likely continue to out-raise Biden through the next two months.

NRA as one major contributor is now under more scrutiny for financial conduct.
The only way I see for POTUS to win this is likely shooting in more of his organizations own money. But with the re-election probability low, I guess he won't...

Despite the points below that 1) Biden isn't a strong fundraiser and 2) incumbents tend to attract more money, it is worth noting that as of June 2020 the two were virtually neck and neck. I'm not sure Trump's base is in a position to contribute and big business may need a different kind of leadership in light of C19 to get the economy on track. I don't particularly have a hunch as to who will raise more, but it'll be close.

Despite lower approval, Trump is running neck-to-neck with Biden. His campaign is better with raising funds and his donors appear to give larger amounts. Biden's delay in announcing VP pick could also contribute to a smaller war chest.
The advantage of incumbency.  Biden has a history of being a terrible fundraiser.
